title: Friday, 2nd December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

This is my last day for a fortnight -- off on hols

PM11:01am

But you'll be in the safe hands of Bryce

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Let's get a pic up

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Stephen Hawking

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Why?

PM11:02am

Well it was only last night that i got to read this

PM11:02am

https://www.thegua...-planet-inequality

11:02 am
BE11:02am

Why?

PM11:02am

Together, they are a reminder that we are at the most dangerous moment in the development of humanity. We now have the technology to destroy the planet on which we live, but have not yet developed the ability to escape it. Perhaps in a few hundred years, we will have established human colonies amid the stars, but right now we only have one planet, and we need to work together to protect it.

To do that, we need to break down, not build up, barriers within and between nations. If we are to stand a chance of doing that, the world’s leaders need to acknowledge that they have failed and are failing the many. With resources increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few, we are going to have to learn to share far more than at present.

PM11:03am

We rallied hard into the close yesterday as oil (up) counteracted sterling (up)

Today we have the latter without the former, with predictable results.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Sterling at a 12-week high on this talk of soft Brexit (and perhaps on Zac's humilating humiliation by the Richmond dog walkers), along with a decent-ish PMI.

BE11:10am

So, miners down. Banks down. Most things down.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,287, down 52.5 (-3.92%), High: 1,303, Low: 1,287, Volume: 2.10m

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 682.50, down 23 (-3.26%), High: 700.00, Low: 680.50, Volume: 1.13m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,945, down 83 (-2.74%), High: 3,000, Low: 2,935, Volume: 845.28k

BE11:11am

(@Patience: agree, pretty much.)

BE11:12am

Credit Suisse is saying sell the UK, if you fancy some of that.

PM11:12am

All of it?

11:12 am
BE11:12am

UK equities cut to underweight from benchmark

BE11:13am

Let me see if I can find it. Searching my email for "2017 strategy" isn't a failsafe method any more.

BE11:13am

Oh! Here we go.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

This is Garthwaite, yeah?

BE11:14am

Equities: We increase our mid-year 2017 target on the S&P 500 to 2,350 from 2,200. The key positive for 2017, in our judgement, is that investors are overweight deflation hedges (i.e. bonds) relative to inflation hedges (equities) at a time when policy makers are moving away from NIRP towards fiscal stimulus, and inflation expectations are set to continue rising. Other supportive factors are: earnings revisions at a five-year high; a still reasonably elevated equity risk premium; excess liquidity; and rising economic momentum.
However, we see a down market in H2 2017, hence our year-end 2017 target of 2,300. The second half challenges include the potential negative impact of US bond yields above 3% (3% being the CS view for end-2017); the growing pricing power of US labour squeezing profit margins; and the risk of China refocusing on reform rather than pro-growth policies. We continue to prefer equities to both bonds and gold. The macro backdrop is one of a modest acceleration in global GDP growth,
with upside risks to the CS view of 3.0% global GDP growth in 2017.

BE11:14am

This is a cast of hundreds, among which Garthwaite gets lead byline.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

See what you mean -- it's 300 pages Omg smile

BE11:15am

All illustrated with a man up a cliff.

BE11:15am

11:15 am
BE11:15am

See? Man up a cliff.

BE11:15am

But back to the writing bit.

BE11:16am

Regions: We add to our overweight in continental European equities (Germany remaining our top pick, upgrading France to benchmark, reducing the size of our underweight of Italy) and we remain overweight in Japanese equities. We reduce the size of our overweight in GEM equities (focusing on China, Taiwan and Korea), and downgrade UK equities to underweight from benchmark. We stay underweight the US in a global context as it is the worst performing market when global growth accelerates, the USD strengthens and bond yields rise; and valuations relative to other regions are extreme.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Cutting to the UK, since we're nothing if not parochial ...

BE11:16am

In our judgement, there are four key elements to a view on UK equities in a global context: sterling, emerging markets, commodities and the global cycle. If we look at these four variables: the outlook for GEM has deteriorated compared to the first 8 months of the year (as we highlight in the GEM section); two factors which had proved tailwinds through the first half of 2016 are now neutral (oil and sterling); and OECD lead indicators are rising, which tends to be negative for UK relative performance.

BE11:17am

So ... Sterling ....

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The UK is one of the most international equity markets globally. Around 70% of UK listed sales are derived overseas, while 40% of dividends are dollar denominated. For the large cap FTSE 100, the international exposure is higher still.

BE11:17am

GEM exposure .........

BE11:18am

Around 18% of UK sales are emerging market related and, if one assumes commodities are a play on GEM growth, then aggregate exposure of the UK to GEM via commodities and direct exposure is c35% of market cap. The relative performance of UK equities has tended to correlate with GEM equities and thus as GEM equities recovered through 2016, this represented a significant tailwind.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

[W]hile emerging market equities are still, in our judgement, an attractive multi-year investment, there are macro challenges as we enter 2017, namely, a stronger dollar, the rise in US real bond
yields, and the increased threat of protectionism. Also, China in 2017 is unlikely to repeat the positive surprise it provided to markets in 2016 at a time when Chinese policy is being
clearly tightened.

BE11:19am

Also, the UK's rubbish.

BE11:19am

The UK equity market's exposure to the UK economy is not exceptionally large, but at around 30% of sales, it is not irrelevant either. While post-Brexit caution on the UK economy was excessive, challenges and risks remain for the UK economy in 2017. Primary among these is a likely sharp rise in the cost of living at a time when the consumer savings ratio is already extremely low by historic standards.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

(Binocular/others -- email me if you like)

BE11:20am

Expect to see more of that quoted a lot in the year-end filler articles we have to write through December, to fill up the space between the adverts.

Laird PLC (LRD:LSE): Last: 136.90, down 14.6 (-9.64%), High: 142.40, Low: 123.50, Volume: 5.65m

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Though you'll remember we've been here before. As in 2009.

BE11:23am

When Laird did a special divi then followed it with a rescue rights.

BE11:23am

You've also got the rejection of the Cooper Industries bid in 2011, which was 185p.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Well, given practice it's had at rescue rights, why haven't they priced this yet?

BE11:24am

Fair question.

PM11:24am

And what's this about "standby" underwriting

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Guess it's "standby" cos it's not priced

BE11:25am

Here's UBS, which has done the dilution maths. Though I can't quite work out how given there's no price.

BE11:25am

While the rights issue is heavily dilutive (47% of the market cap
at close 1/12/16) we believe this should draw a line under the difficulties of 2016 and Laird can now move on under new management with cost savings accordingly to drive EBIT improvement in FY17E ($15m of the $20m annual saving plan expected in FY17).

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Laird's operating performance is aligned with prior commentary (c.£50m, UBSe £48m) with growth seen in connected vehicle systems (CVS seen as a $500m+ revenue business in 2020 vs $330m in FY16) and weakness in Performance Materials. We believe the difficulties have centred on pricing rather than volume reflecting both price downs at Apple as well as poor execution on price by Laird itself (we note a change in management at Performance Materials). This may take some time to remedy but we believe the company is likely to see several drivers for profit growth in 2017E: 1) Cost saving 2) Novero moving to a modest profit (a £9m swing) 3) Remedial price action. 4) Leverage in the CVS business. 5) FX benefits. This will likely be mitigated by 1) staff bonuses 2) annualising some of the weaker pricing in H1.

BE11:26am

Given the in-line trading statement we do not expect changes in operational forecasting through the P&L, though consensus EPS will likely be diluted by the rights issue. In addition management cited in the conference call that the company may close FY17 with a slightly heavier net debt position than previously expected (£330-350m vs UBSe/cons c.£290-300m) reflecting currency movements. On this basis, we estimate Laird will likely optically break covenants at the end of FY16 (greater than 3.5x EBITDA); on an average basis (the way we believe the covenants are structured) Laird may fall below this but with the rights issue this will be addressed.

PM11:26am

So they are not actually doing this rights until early next year

11:26 am
PM11:27am

intends to undertake a Rights Issue to raise up to £185 million, underwritten on a standby basis by J.P. Morgan Cazenove. The Rights Issue is anticipated to be launched in Q1 2017 together with the full year results. The standby agreement contains representations and warranties, undertakings, conditions, indemnities and termination rights, including an undertaking to reduce the nominal value from 28 pence per share to 1 pence per share, if required.

PM11:27am

That's from the statement

BE11:27am

We've seen this structure before, right? And seen death spirals form because of it? Didn't Lonmin do things this way?

PM11:27am

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Oh! Here's a man we can safely call one of "the elite". Anyway. Here's Barclays, which as I say was predicting this last month.

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

BE11:29am

And Numis. (I know this is all a bit repetitious.)

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Looking into FY17E, there are a number of things which should improve performance. The operational improvement plan is on track to deliver annualized savings of at least $20m/£16m, with $15m/£12m expected in FY17E. The Novero business, acquired in Dec-2015, is now fully integrated into the group and is expected to make a modest profit in FY17E (from a c.£10m loss in FY16E). The actions being taken in PM should also improve profitability. While there is likely to be some offset from opex increases and we are allowing for other contingencies, we upgrade FY17E EBIT to £75m from £67m (a £14m improvement from £61m in FY16E).
● We now expect the change in profit mix to result in a increased tax rate at 30% in FY16E/17E (from 20%). The final dividend for FY16 will be cancelled and in FY17E, the payout ratio will be 30% (increasing to 50% in the medium term). We expect net debt at Dec-16 at £350m (previously £305m) reflecting impact of FX and also higher capex and capitalized R&D (whilst this equals 3.6x EBITDA, it would not breach covenants as these use an average FX rate). To reflect the rights issue, we model a £185m equity issue in Q1 priced at 150p. The rights issue should allow financial flexibility to deliver on the new operating model savings, increase customer confidence and provide a foundation to "assess the optimal route to maximize value in Peformance Materials". We forecast net debt at £197m at Dec-17, equivalent to 1.8x EBITDA.

BE11:32am

There's a broader conversation here about how Apple's multiple sourcing policy's pretty much destroyed the suppliers in its chain that are a bit flabby or a bit shambolic, though we've had that conversation quite often already.

BE11:32am

So, let's move on.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 2,666, up 121 (+4.75%), High: 2,679, Low: 2,611, Volume: 932.77k
11:33 am
PM11:34am

Saying the "markets undervaluing us"

PM11:34am

This recognises that, at certain price points, the Board is of the opinion that the Company is materially undervalued and share buy-backs will be in the best interests of all shareholders.

BE11:34am

That's the one. You'll remember when Next deployed this policy.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Ah, did they?

BE11:35am

Yup. Balancing cash returns based on management's understanding of where the shares ought to be trading. It works for as long as it does, and then it doesn't.

PM11:35am

You'd kinda think they should concentrate on building houses, rather lecturing to the equity market

11:35 am
BE11:36am

On that theme, we also get a bunch of new five-year targets.

BE11:36am

The three-year target is unchanged. But Berkeley also know what London's newbuild property market will look like in 2022, which is reassuring.

BE11:37am

Here's Canaccord.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Strong set of interim results with PBT of £392m ahead of our top end forecast of £379m. Management has reiterated its 3 year PBT target of £2bn but also announced a new five year target to deliver at least £3bn of PBT in the five years beginning May 2016. The other important announcement is that future capital returns are to be made through a mixture of dividends and share buy-backs, not only dividends. Recent trading looks to have stabilised at recent levels seeing reservations down by c.20% year on year. New launches are planned for the New Year. These results show the quality within the group and the confidence of management to give more visibility over profits for two years beyond the 3 year £2bn PBT target. Clearly, management also sees value in the shares, given it comments on the potential for share buy backs with the quantum of the £10 of capital return being unchanged if share buy backs are used rather than dividends. Consensus for the next two years is unlikely to change significantly but there is now more guidance beyond the FY 2018.

BE11:37am

Results detail

Turnover was up by +24% to £1,413m with completions of 2,076 and ASP of £655k (2015: £506k).
Operating profit was up +34% at c.£391m with gross margins up over 100bps.
PBT of £392.7m was ahead of our top end forecast of £379m.
NAV per share was up by +7.9% to 1,418p. Net cash was £208m, broadly as expected.
Forward sales of £2.9bn with £5.9bn of estimated future gross margin in the land bank.
Reservations continue to run down by around 20%, which suggests the market has stabilised in recent months.

BE11:37am

Valuation

Shares are down by c.30% YTD and are one of the largest fallers in the sector. Shares reside on a FY 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.1.6 times, virtually in line with the sector average, and offer an attractive dividend yield of c.+.8%. Potential share buy-backs highlight management's view of value within the land bank/shares.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

You'll remember Berkeley was the default short going into Brexit. We wrote a bunch of stories about it in February.

PM11:40am

Pidgley seem to be furious about that -- took it personally

BE11:41am

Well, the short interest also reflected some concerns about their book-keeping methods, which I can't find in the archive immediately.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

In terms of when they book a sale as a sale. Revenue recognition stuff.

BE11:41am

Here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-02-18/

BE11:42am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

That's yesterday's news though. Have some Davy.

BE11:42am

Weaker sales rates this year in the higher end of the London
housing market have driven down forward sales and future
gross margin at Berkeley. The new five-year guidance suggests
a materially lower profitability level in the latter part of this
decade as the current exceptionally high margins normalise.
However, the introduction of potential buybacks may temper
too much negativity.

BE11:43am

Current sales remain sluggish, as previous flagged. Berkeley continues to see reservations (excluding a hiatus around Brexit) running at a level about 20% below last year. The slower sales rate has driven a decline in the forward order book, with forward sales now at £2.9bn (from £3.25bn in April). Pricing remains resilient, according to the company, but it has been forced to absorb the increases in stamp duty at higher price points. Cost inflation is continuing, albeit at lower rates. The company is currently seeing build cost inflation running at c.4%.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Berkeley has also seen the gross margin fall in the land bank. From a level of £6.1bn in April, this now stands at £5.9bn in October. While this is somewhat driven by a lower number of plots in the land bank (42,125 versus 42,858), the profitability per plot has also fallen slightly.

BE11:43am

But enough DPL.

PM11:48am

The Company has identified attractive investment opportunities in both its current portfolio of 26 subsidiaries as well as what the directors believe to be a strong pipeline of innovative new technologies. To capitalise on additional growth and development opportunities, it is expected that a number of subsidiaries will look to raise capital over the course of 2017-18. The proceeds of the Placing will enable the Company to maintain majority ownership in its subsidiaries where possible and minimise dilution in further fundraising rounds. In addition, the proceeds will allow the Company to continue to invest in and develop innovative new technologies and IP from universities, federal research labs and strategic partners. The board of directors of the Company believes the policy of protecting existing subsidiary shareholdings and continuing to invest in the pipeline is the right approach for the Company and will maximise value for all shareholders.

BE11:53am

11:53 am
undefined
PM11:54am

Indeed

BE11:55am

(@estrangedcapitalist: FGS, man, start with small amounts.)

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Sellside wise, there are a few things to note.

BE11:55am

RBC downgrading EasyJet, for instance.

BE11:56am

Growth vs. dividend tension unresolved: Previously we saw a need for easyJet to reflect the deflationary fare backdrop (we see persisting) with (1) a lower DPS or a revised fleet capex plan (RBCe lease adjusted ND/EBITDA sees ~3x 2019E); and/or (2) proof of accelerating unit cost improvement as fleet growth (+30% by 2020E) moves to more competitive airports. Neither have been delivered, and nor have we seen any signs of meaningful competitor capacity exits needed to stabilize market supply/demand imbalances.

11:55 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 978.50, down 18 (-1.81%), High: 985.00, Low: 963.00, Volume: 733.27k
BE11:56am

Timing of fare/pricing recovery is crucial – otherwise an equity downside squeeze (out of the EV) is likely: Strategy in essence is more of the same. This delivered 2016’s 32% fall in PBT/seat, and is set to deliver 2017E PBT/seat down 49% 2YoY, EPS deterioration (-26% YoY, -43% 2YoY) and lease-adjusted debt leverage expansion – in the company’s hope of eventual long-term gain. To work, we think easyJet’s strategy needs fares to recover quicker than rate of balance sheet deterioration. If easyJet has misjudged its timing then equity shareholders risk being squeezed out of the EV before the pricing cycle recovers. We see this risk growing.

BE11:56am

Lots of hedged fuel in Europe is why we think fare price recovery will take longer: Europe’s highly hedged airlines mean share gain (not margin) focused supply growth is set to continue in 2017 and possibly 2018. Europe’s major airlines see USD fuel cost/tonne fall 17% 2017E (-11% at spot EURUSD). Tellingly, 2017 spot fuel would need to be 80% higher at over US$880/tonne for USD unit fuel costs not to fall. This suggests Europe’s airlines still have an incentive to grow market share (not margin) in 2017. Continued high growth or accelerated plans for 2017 are suggested by recent remarks from Air France KLM, Eurowings, Jet2, Ryanair, TAP, Transavia, Wizz Air – and easyJet itself. If these are not dampened down as 2017 develops this could see RBCe base case 2% easyJet average fare/RASK decline at risk. A move down to unit revenue fall seen in prior ‘growth periods’ could expand downside to 740p or lower.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

We rate Underperform with ~10% implied downside to our PT on (1) easyJet’s 14%-24% PER premium; (2) lower RoE than Ryanair and Wizz Air at a higher PER (Ryanair also offers exposure to any eventual inflection to rising W European fares); (3) high (~49% revenue) UK exposure (consumer risk); (4) shrinking profits; (5) negative equity free cash flow and rising debt/lease liabilities. Our scenarios based PT implies 11.4x YA PER vs. median 11.7x.

BE11:57am

900p target ......

BE11:57am

Our PT implies 11.4x YA vs. 5-year median 11.3x PER and 10-year median 11.7x.

11:57 am

11:59 am

BE11:59am

SocGen pushing Shire.

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,595, up 40 (+0.88%), High: 4,610, Low: 4,510, Volume: 504.73k
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Usual argument. "Baxalta's not that bad," in summary.

BE12:00pm

Clearly it's not as good as Actelion. But we still don't know if Actelion will ever actually be sold (please stop calling, we genuinely don't know).

BE12:00pm

Here's the upshot of SG.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

We initiate coverage with a Buy rating and 6,500p target price. Shire stock is a consensual long but we find many investors remain sceptical in light of concerns over potential competitive headwinds to Shire’s marketleading haemophilia franchise from 2H17. In our view both this risk and our worst-case scenario (see below) are fully discounted at current levels, with the stock trading on near record low P/Es. Going forward, we expect share price outperformance to be driven by positive earnings surprises sourced from both top line and margins.

PM12:01pm

blimey

BE12:01pm

I know, right!

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

We forecast upside surprise Our EPS estimates are up to 9% higher than consensus on higher sales and margin assumptions. Our sales estimates are up to 7% above as we are more bullish on Xiidra (eye drug), Vyvanse (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity) and the base business. We forecast greater margin expansion as we expect Shire to exceed its year three $700m costs savings target associated with the Baxalta acquisition.
The stock is undervalued The stock screens favourably on most regression analyses as investors are concerned about the sustainability of Shire’s market-leading haemophilia franchise post the launch of Roche’s potentially disruptive ACE910 in 2H17/1H18. Our Shire group sales and EPS estimates imply upside surprise potential vs consensus even though our ACE910 estimates are 9-11% ahead of consensus. Hence, we think this risk is already fully discounted, and the market is thus undervaluing Shire’s growth prospects. Our valuation As for all other stocks in our global coverage universe, our target price (TP) is based on a straight average of short-term EV/EBITA multiples (no premium/discount to sector, £57) and a DCF (£73, 8% WACC, 2% perp. growth from 2037). Bloomberg shows our TP is the highest on the sell side. However, our TP implies a bare 11% premium to the sector average P/E 17e even though we expect the top line to surprise on the upside and Shire to deliver above-average sales and EPS growth. Buy.

BE12:01pm

And the worst case is discounted Our bear case assumes that recently launched Xiidra (eye drug) is withdrawn from the US on safety concerns (-£5.5), rival ACE910 proves 50% more successful than we assume in our base case (-£4.5) and the entire late stage pipeline fails (-£5.0). If all three risks materialised there would be 22% downside to our 2022 EBIT estimate and our valuation would drop to £52.5, all else equal.
But it’s not a dividend story Until 2022 Shire’s strategic priority is to repay the $21bn debt raised to finance the Baxalta deal. Hence the stock is not a dividend story.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

[W]e had suggested to achieve balance sheet leverage of 2.5-2.0x net debt/EBITDA at the end of FY17E would need an equity raise of £75m-125m and that this might have been 12-19% dilutive to EPS (bonus element adjusted). “The Board is targeting a capital structure between 1.0x to 2.0x net debt to EBITDA in the medium term”. Management is clearly taking a more conservative view with regard to repairing its debt position and it may also suggest our current year-end net debt of £304m (3.3x EBITDA) may prove to be optimistic.

Operational improvement programme remains on track, saving $20m from 2018 and $15m in 2017. Wireless Systems has fully integrated Novero and expected to make a “modest profit” in 2017 (as before). No 2016 final dividend expected to be paid with a modest H1 17E dividend based on 3x cover.
